title: Joseph in Potiphar's House
shortSummary: Genesis 39 recounts Joseph's rise to prominence in Potiphar's household in Egypt, his steadfast refusal to sin against God despite temptation, and his subsequent imprisonment due to false accusation. This chapter highlights God's providential presence and faithfulness in the life of Joseph, even amid trials.
timeline: c. 1898 BC - Joseph's early years in Egypt during the time of the patriarchs

keyCharacters.name: Joseph
keyCharacters.description: Son of Jacob, sold into slavery, who serves faithfully in Potiphar's house and later in prison, demonstrating integrity and God's favor.

keyCharacters.name: Potiphar
keyCharacters.description: An Egyptian officer of Pharaoh and captain of the guard who purchases Joseph and entrusts him with his household.

keyCharacters.name: Potiphar's Wife
keyCharacters.description: The wife of Potiphar who attempts to seduce Joseph and falsely accuses him when he resists.

keyCharacters.name: Keeper of the Prison
keyCharacters.description: The official in charge of the prison who places Joseph in authority over the other prisoners due to God's favor.

definitions.definition: Descendants of Ishmael; a group of traders who sold Joseph into slavery in Egypt.
A person appointed to supervise and manage the affairs of a household or property.
To insult or treat with contempt; here used by Potiphar's wife to falsely accuse Joseph of attempting to seduce her.
A high-ranking officer responsible for the security of the king or Pharaoh's household.

outline.heading: Joseph's Service and Prosperity in Potiphar's House
outline.description: Joseph is sold to Potiphar and quickly gains favor because the LORD is with him, resulting in his promotion to overseer of Potiphar's household and blessing over all possessions.

outline.heading: Temptation and Refusal
outline.description: Potiphar's wife attempts to seduce Joseph, but he refuses to sin against God and his master, demonstrating moral integrity and faithfulness.

outline.heading: False Accusation and Imprisonment
outline.description: After Joseph flees, Potiphar's wife falsely accuses him of attempted assault, leading to Joseph's imprisonment despite his innocence.

outline.heading: God's Favor in Prison
outline.description: Even in prison, the LORD remains with Joseph, granting him mercy and favor, and placing him in charge of the other prisoners, showing God's providential care.

application: Trust in God's presence and providence even in difficult or unjust circumstances, knowing He can bless and prosper your efforts.
Maintain moral integrity and resist temptation, recognizing that sin is ultimately against God and harms your witness.
Respond to false accusations and trials with faithfulness, trusting God to vindicate and sustain you.
Seek to serve faithfully in every situation, whether in positions of authority or in hardship, as a testimony of God's grace.

keyVerses.text: And the LORD was with Joseph, and he was a prosperous man; and he was in the house of his master the Egyptian.
keyVerses.significance: This verse emphasizes God's abiding presence as the source of Joseph's success and blessing.

keyVerses.text: There is none greater in this house than I; neither hath he kept back any thing from me but thee, because thou art his wife: how then can I do this great wickedness, and sin against God?
keyVerses.significance: Joseph's refusal to sin highlights his reverence for God and commitment to righteousness despite temptation.

keyVerses.text: But the LORD was with Joseph, and shewed him mercy, and gave him favour in the sight of the keeper of the prison.
keyVerses.significance: God's mercy and favor continue to sustain Joseph even in imprisonment, demonstrating divine faithfulness.
